title: How to Measure the Remaining Propane

steps.title: Engraved on the side of the tank should be the letters TW then a number.
steps.content: Engraved on the side of the tank should be the letters TW then a number. This number is the empty tank weight. For example, the typical 5 gallon (18.9 L) propane tank might say TW 17.2. The weight of the empty tank in the example is 17.2 lbs. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Weigh the tank on a bathroom scale to find the total current weight.
steps.content: Weigh the tank on a bathroom scale to find the total current weight. Let's say that the current weight of the tank is 24.2 lbs. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Subtract the tank weight from the total weight to find the weight of the propane.
steps.content: Subtract the tank weight from the total weight to find the weight of the propane. 24.2 lbs - 17.2 lbs = 7 lbs. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Each pound of propane contains 21,600 BTUs.
steps.content: Each pound of propane contains 21,600 BTUs. [4] X Research source Multiply the number of pounds by the number of BTUs contained in each to get the total number of BTUs remaining in the tank. 7 × 21,600 ≈ 151,000 BTUs.

steps.title: Find the BTU output of the appliance in question.
steps.content: Find the BTU output of the appliance in question. These can often be found on manufacturers web sites. For example a propane grill may burn 12,000 BTUs an hour. To find the remaining running time for the grill divide 151,000 by 12,000. 151,000 ÷ 12,000 ≈ 12.6 hours of run time. [5] X Research source

steps.title: For easy future reference.
steps.content: For easy future reference. divide 12.6 hours by the aforementioned 7 lbs to get 1.8 hours of grill run time per pound of bathroom scale measured propane. [6] X Research source
